<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/31  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 265, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Theory (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 728, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<label>1</label>

Fig. 1.1 shows a coil of wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 310, 920, 344]]<|/det|>

On Fig. 6.1, an arrow points to the temperature reading when the thermometer is placed in pure melting ice. This is labelled **ice point**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 439, 920, 473]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

A liquid-in-glass thermometer uses the property of expansion of a liquid to measure temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 702, 551]]<|/det|>
State **one** other application or consequence of thermal expansion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 594, 920, 613]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 144, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 625, 670, 644]]<|/det|>
A student is testing how different surfaces absorb radiant heat.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 655, 920, 705]]<|/det|>
The student puts two metal plates in holders and places them on either side of a radiant heater as shown in Fig. 6.2. One plate has a shiny metal side facing towards the heater and the other plate has a dull black side facing towards the heater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 718, 559, 736]]<|/det|>
A metal disc is attached to each plate using wax.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 746, 892, 883]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 902, 532, 920]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
The student turns on the radiant heater and starts a stop-clock. The wax on the plate with a dull black side melts and the metal disc falls off the plate 53 seconds after the stop-clock is started.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
The metal disc on the plate with a shiny metal side remains attached for another 32 seconds after the metal disc on the first plate falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
Explain why the metal disc on the plate with a dull black side falls before the metal disc on the plate with a shiny metal side.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 351, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 380, 181, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 380, 920, 413]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 426, 520, 444]]<|/det|>
